questions.question_text:
The implementations group has been using the test bed to do a "˜proof-of-concept' that requires both Client 1 and Client 2 to access the WEB Server at
209.65.200.241. After several changes to the network addressing, routing schemes, DHCP services, NTP services, layer 2 connectivity, FHRP services, and device security, a trouble ticket has been opened indicating that Client 1 cannot ping the 209.65.200.241 address.
Use the supported commands to isolate the cause of this fault and answer the following question.
What is the solution to the fault condition?

discussion.content:
this configuration is not under the pool:
R1(config)#ip dhcp excluded-address 192.168.10.1

questions.answer_description: On R4 the DHCP IP address is not allowed for network 10.2.1.0/24 which clearly shows the problem lies on R4 & the problem is with DHCP

choices.D: Under the IP DHCP pool configuration, issue the no ip dhcp excluded-address 10.2.1.1 10.2.1.253 command and enter the ip dhcp excluded-address 10.2.1.1 10.2.1.2 command. D
choices.C: Under the IP DHCP pool configuration, delete the network 10.2.1.0 255.255.255.0 command and enter the network 10.1.4.0 255.255.255.0 command.
choices.A: Under the global configuration, delete the no ip dhcp use vrf connected command.
choices.B: Under the IP DHCP pool configuration, delete the default -router 10.2.1.254 command and enter the default-router 10.1.4.5 command.

questions.question_text:
The implementation group has been using the test bed to do an IPv6 'proof-of-concept1. After several changes to the network addressing and routing schemes, a trouble ticket has been opened indicating that the loopback address on R1 (2026::111:1) is not able to ping the loopback address on DSW2 (2026::102:1).
Use the supported commands to isolate the cause of this fault and answer the following question.
The fault condition is related to which technology?

discussion.content: I think C is the correct

comments.content:
Exact, there is a mistake
C. IPv6 OSPF Routing is correct

questions.answer_description: Since we are unable to ping the IPv6 address, the problem is with IPv6 OSPF Routing.
The problem here is that VLAN 10 is not configured on the proper interfaces on switch ASW1.
questions.question_text:
The implementations group has been using the test bed to do a "˜proof-of-concept' that requires both Client 1 and Client 2 to access the WEB Server at
209.65.200.241. After several changes to the network addressing, routing scheme, DHCP services, NTP services, layer 2 connectivity, FHRP services, and device security, a trouble ticket has been opened indicating that Client 1 cannot ping the 209.65.200.241 address.
Use the supported commands to isolated the cause of this fault and answer the following questions.
What is the solution to the fault condition?

choices.D: In Configuration mode, using the interface range Fastethernet 1/0/1 "" 2, then switchport access vlan 10 command. D
choices.C: In Configuration mode, using the interface range Fastethernet 1/0/1 "" 2, then switchport vlan 10 access command.
choices.B: In Configuration mode, using the interface range Fastethernet 1/0/1 "" 2, then switchport access mode vlan 10 command.
choices.A: In Configuration mode, using the interface range Fastethernet 1/0/1 "" 2, then switchport mode access vlan 10 command.

questions.question_text:
The implementations group has been using the test bed to do a "˜proof-of-concept' that requires both Client 1 and Client 2 to access the WEB Server at
209.65.200.241. After several changes to the network addressing, routing scheme, DHCP services, NTP services, layer 2 connectivity, FHRP services, and device security, a trouble ticket has been opened indicating that Client 1 cannot ping the 209.65.200.241 address.
Use the supported commands to isolated the cause of this fault and answer the following questions.
What is the solution to the fault condition?
questions.answer_description: The problem here is that VLAN 10 is not configured on the proper interfaces on switch ASW1.

choices.D: Remove the distribute-list command from the EIGRP 200 routing process in R2.
choices.A: Change the autonomous system number in the remainder of the network to be consistent with R2 and R4.
choices.E: Remove the distribute-list command from the EIGRP 100 routing process in R2. B
choices.C: Enable the R2 and R4 router interfaces connected to the 192.168.24.0 network.
choices.B: Move the 192.168.24.0 network to the EIGRP 1 routing process in R2 and R4.

questions.answer_description: When issuing the "show ip eigrp neighbor" command (which is about the only command that it lets you do in this question) you will see that all other routers are configured for EIGRP AS 1. However, the 192.16824.0 network between R2 and R4 is incorrectly configured for EIGRP AS 100:
